snippet.textDisplay: When I first saw this movie I was surprised that Gonzo stuck (mostly) to the Original Dickens text. As you pointed out, this is a very good version of "A Christmas Carol," but it's second best, only topped by the Patrick Stewart version of 1999. That version is the only version that gets the timing of the three ghosts' visits right: "Expect the first to-morrow, when the bell tolls One (Note: AM). Expect the second on the next night at the same hour. The third upon the next night when the last stroke of Twelve has ceased to vibrate." That's the reason Scrooge, hanging out of his window and hearing it's Christmas says "The spirits have done it all in one night! Well, of course they can; they can do anything they like!" The other movies have him say it, but it's out of place because it's scripted for all three to visit on the same night. Another thing many of the films miss is Scrooge's sister's name: it's "Fan," not "Fran." (Hell, his nephew, Fan's son, is "Fred," but the musical calls him "Harry!")
snippet.textOriginal: When I first saw this movie I was surprised that Gonzo stuck (mostly) to the Original Dickens text.  As you pointed out, this is a very good version of "A Christmas Carol," but it's _second_ best, only topped by the Patrick Stewart version of 1999.  That version is the _only_ version that gets the timing of the three ghosts' visits right: "Expect the first to-morrow, when the bell tolls One (Note: AM).  Expect the second on the next night at the same hour.  The third upon the next night when the last stroke of Twelve has ceased to vibrate."  _That's_ the reason Scrooge, hanging out of his window and hearing it's Christmas says "The spirits have done it all in one night!  Well, of course they can; they can do anything they like!"  The other movies have him say it, but it's out of place because it's scripted for all three to visit on the same night.  Another thing many of the films miss is Scrooge's sister's name: it's "Fan," not "Fran."  (Hell, his nephew, Fan's son, is "Fred," but the musical calls him "Harry!")

snippet.textDisplay:
Ok. These are Muppets. They come with their own set of movie rules. SO... #1 theLogo thing is right. But the Kermit logo is beloved, Jeremy. And I don't remember seeing the Disney logo at all in theaters. That's a dvd thing for kids born too late to know how it was first released. Blame Disney post 2008 for that. #2 London is a puppet set designed to look fake, is that confusing for you? #3 Yeah, they're pigs. in a Muppet movie. #4-5 Sentient and non-sentient fruit. Again, MUPPETS. This is sad, man. I feel like this will be the entire review... #6-7 WTF you got against Gonzo, man? He's a sweetie!
#8. Ok, 2 Marleys I get. That's against the book, there are a few sins against the book in this retelling with puppets for family audiences, but this is trying to be as lighthearted as possible and the Marleys as the 2 old hecklers was a funny at multiple times in their song. And they were grave and left me thinking "woah... what did these guys suffer since they died?" during a song as a 9 year old. For muppets, this is intense; describing Avarice and Greed, wearing chains and telling Scrooge "a nightmare waits for you". This is heavy for muppets. This is the heaviest story they've ever taken on, in fact. I was impressed at the age of 9, back in '92. My mom asked if I had to leave the theater. I asked if SHE was ok at that, but the same thing happened when I was 11 watching Jurassic park in theaters, so yeah...
#9 The term 'rouge' was actually used VERY commonly by women in the late 80s - early 90s. The term 'blush' was never used at all till after 2000. It was a different age, makeup wasn't as diverse as it is today. Also, the slang "spooge" literally didn't exist at all. And it's kinda gross that you want muppets to sing about spooge, frankly. A sin against you, man. You can't just uphold every film you want to attack like it was born in the pitiful emojiverse of 2019 when it's from another century altogether where cellphones didn't exist in film (The X files brick cellphones used by the FBI back then didn't even come into film til 1995, get your headspace right before doing these reviews. You're calling everything a sin to be created before 2013. WTF, man?) because you need to invent another fake sin for your meter every 60 seconds or less. That's milking it. HARD. Talk about being an eggplant. In 1992 an eggplant was just an eggplant. Grow up.
#10 It's called a puppet, stupid. This is a movie starring puppets. How much of this concept do you need to be spoonfed before you catch on? A LOT, it appears, because you flail around in this review like a desperate toddler who can't figure out where the plate of food you're trying to eat even is.

I'd like to keep going through the whole thing, but I have to put my own 4 little ones to bed this Christmas night. <3 Love your videos. This one was just wrong. But a shoutout to this film in any way is always understandable. Who doesn't check out Muppets videos? :) Merry Christmas!
snippet.textOriginal:

snippet.textDisplay: This movie is perfect, friend. Even mistakes are charming and wonderful in this film, it even has a gag reel. The muppets make mistakes, it's part of their identity. As someone who was lucky enough to see this film in theaters as a little girl, everyone in the theater cried and adored it. Why these songs aren't on the radio each year blows me away. I had to buy the soundtrack for my kids. It's hard to find a real Sin here without reaching desperate levels. It's funny you tried, but... no, man... sorry.
snippet.textOriginal: This movie is perfect, friend. Even mistakes are charming and wonderful in this film, it even has a gag reel. The muppets make mistakes, it's part of their identity. I had to buy the soundtrack for my kids. It's hard to find a real Sin here without reaching desperate levels. It's funny you tried, but... no, man... sorry.

snippet.textDisplay:
Falun Gong practitioners in New Zealand's North Island participated in five different Christmas parades on Saturday, November 30 and Sunday, December 1, 2019.

To join all five of the parades, practitioners needed to break up into smaller teams. The Tian Guo Marching Band participated in the Christmas parade in Tauranga on Saturday and the parade in Devonport, Auckland, on Sunday. The waist drum team and the float participated in the Christmas parade in Manurewa on Saturday and Palmerston North on Sunday. The dragon dance team participated in the Christmas parade in Ellerslie, Auckland, on Sunday.
snippet.textOriginal:
Falun Gong practitioners in New Zealand's North Island participated in five different Christmas parades on Saturday, November 30 and Sunday, December 1, 2019. 

To join all five of the parades, practitioners needed to break up into smaller teams. The Tian Guo Marching Band participated in the Christmas parade in Tauranga on Saturday and the parade in Devonport, Auckland, on Sunday. The waist drum team and the float participated in the Christmas parade in Manurewa on Saturday and Palmerston North on Sunday. The dragon dance team participated in the Christmas parade in Ellerslie, Auckland, on Sunday.

snippet.textDisplay:
Scrooge's "evilness" was in that he wasn't generous despite his wealth (and that he might have also taken advantage of the poor). That's why him using his ample wealth to help others is considered to be a good thing.

Also, it's important to remember that the story only ever takes place on Christmas or Christmas Eve (except for the Patrick Stewart one that also briefly takes place on the day afterwards) and we'll never see what other things Scrooge does to prove that he is truly reformed.

Note: Only reason I mention this is because it's the only sin that Jeremy seems to take seriously.
snippet.textOriginal:
Scrooge's "evilness" was in that he wasn't generous despite his wealth (and that he might have also taken advantage of the poor).  That's why him using his ample wealth to help others is considered to be a good thing.

Also, it's important to remember that the story only ever takes place on Christmas or Christmas Eve (except for the Patrick Stewart one that also briefly takes place on the day afterwards) and we'll never see what other things Scrooge does to prove that he is truly reformed.

Note: Only reason I mention this is because it's the only sin that Jeremy seems to take seriously.

I actually thought of a sin for this during my yearly watching of it
During the Marley and Marley song
"I remember the time we evicted the entire orphanage"
except that at the time this is set there were no private orphanages... meaning all of them would be funded by the government... so unless the queen ran out of money one christmas there's no way they'd be evicting anyone from that place

snippet.textDisplay: 1:53 - That creature next to the Porcupine is an Inkspot and they originated from Fraggle Rock (another Jim Henson production). Turns out this film and Muppet Treasure Island respectively featured characters from Fraggle Rock making cameos as Background puppets, Sprockit being one of them.

snippet.textDisplay:
Well..... if you want to get really technical, cheese for mice is more folklore than anything and peanut butter makes for better mousetrap bait.
So.... a rabbit is a lagomorph, not a rodent.
It is among the best versions of Christmas Carol I've seen, and the way that young lady with no dialog only a song with a pre-set tone that remains even managed to emote going from hurt and unsure to resolute... cutting the "Love is Gone" song was a serious disservice to her.
snippet.textOriginal:
Well..... if you want to get really technical, cheese for mice is more folklore than anything and peanut butter makes for better mousetrap bait.
So.... a rabbit is a lagomorph, not a rodent.
It is among the best versions of Christmas Carol I've seen, and the way that young lady with no dialog only a song with a pre-set tone that remains even managed to emote going from hurt and unsure to resolute... cutting the "Love is Gone" song was a serious disservice to her.
